Award.AwardTitle: MATH: CONFERENCE: Broadening Participation in Mathematics Education through Practitioner Inquiry

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
A National priority is to increase the diversity of the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) workforce. One important way to accomplish this is to increase the racial and ethnic diversity of students entering and graduating in STEM disciplines. In line with this, mathematics faculty members play a significant role as instructors, mentors, and curriculum developers in student success and progress towards a STEM degree. However, few mathematics faculty are provided professional training that exposes them to teaching practices tailored to support the success, for example, of African American, Latino, and Native American students. This project is a conference/workshop with a threefold purpose. (1) The investigators will engage approximately thirty-five (35) mathematics faculty members from community colleges in Colorado - where mathematics curriculum reform is already underway - in learning techniques to develop culturally inclusive pedagogical practices and increase the success of historically underserved students in mathematics coursework. These techniques are based on an approach to data use and educational change known as practitioner inquiry. Recent studies of curricular and pedagogical reforms in STEM fields provide evidence that strategies involving practitioner inquiry are promising approaches to bringing about cultural and organizational change. (2) The researchers will gather information on conference participants' willingness to undertake curriculum reforms, and if so, under what conditions of institutional support. (3) Conference evaluation results will be analyzed to design future interventions involving mathematics faculty in community colleges, thereby supporting a United States goal to broaden participation in STEM.

The main goals of the workshop are to gauge faculty attitudes, beliefs, and willingness to engage in inquiry as a technique to enable math faculty to incorporate new knowledge and cultural competencies into their educational practice. The conference evaluation will support the investigation by exploring the following research questions: What information, concepts, and models from existing practice stimulate interest among mathematics educators to learn about culturally inclusive pedagogies? What information, concepts, and models from existing practice have a positive influence on mathematics educators' intentions to participate in practitioner inquiry and carry out curricular and pedagogical changes designed to broaden participation in mathematics coursework? Mathematics faculty members' experience of the conference will inform the design of new inquiry methods as well as outreach and dissemination strategies that further promote mathemtics faculty implementation of culturally inclusive pedagogy.

ProgramReference.Text: Math Success in First 2 Years of College

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project had three major goals that were achieved by convening a 1.5 day conference for community college faculty math faculty members. The Broadening Participation in Mathematics Education through Practitioner Inquiry Conference was convened by the principal investigators and professional staff members of the Center for Urban Education (CUE) and mathematics faculty members from the Community College of Aurora (CCA), Colorado, on Oct. 22-23, 2015 at CCA’s Centretech Campus. Through presentations, discussions, and activities, 31 faculty members from 8 of the 13 colleges in the Colorado community college system were introduced to the ways practitioner inquiry can be used to support the success of African American, Latino, and Native American students in mathematics. Participating faculty represented the mathematics departments at the Community College of Denver, Northeastern Junior College, Front Range Community College, Trinidad State Junior College, Morgan Junior College, Arapahoe Community College, Pikes Peak College, and Pueblo Community College. 

The first goal of hosting the Broadening Participation in Mathematics Education through Practitioner Inquiry Conference was to introduce participating mathematics educators to the concepts, methods, and desired outcomes of practitioner inquiry (a form of action research that involves self-study). The second goal was to gauge community college mathematics faculty members' attitudes and beliefs about using inquiry as a strategy to accomplish institutional, curricular, and pedagogical reforms based in culturally inclusive practices in order to broaden participation of African Americans, Latinos, and Native Americans in mathematics. The third goal was to assess the willingness of mathematics educators to engage in inquiry for the purpose of designing culturally inclusive pedagogies if given the opportunity to do so in the future. 

The key outcomes were: (1) the investigators successfully hosted a conference that effectively communicated the key concepts indicated in the conference proposal to the desired target audience of community college mathematics faculty members; (2) the conference was well received by participants, whose evaluation responses indicated they had positive learning experiences; (3) high quality data were collected and analyzed to answer the research questions that were posed as part of the investigator’s larger research agenda focused on broadening participation in STEM.

 

The findings of this project provide strong evidence that, in a learning and professional development environment such as that created by the Broadening Participation in Mathematics through Practitioner Inquiry conference, community college mathematics faculty members view culturally inclusive pedagogies as relevant to their own classrooms and that they would be interested and willing to engage in inquiry to develop culturally inclusive pedagogies if provided with adequate time and leadership support. Having experienced a high quality introduction to the concepts of equity, inquiry, and culturally inclusive pedagogies, conference participants viewed racial equity goals as important and perceived inquiry as a viable strategy to broaden participation in mathematics.

 

The findings also show that participating faculty had a sense of agency to engage in professional development using inquiry methods to broaden participation in mathematics. However, there was a high degree of uncertainty as to how faculty colleagues who had not attended the conference would respond to such an opportunity or whether campus leaders would support an inquiry process with the time and resources (e.g. data) to the degree necessary for faculty to engage successfully in the process.

The broader impact on the field will evolve from the work of holding this conference, because the principal investigators learned that under certain conditions math faculty were willing, able, and interested to use the principles of equity and culturally inclusive pedagogies that had been presented. Holding the conference funded by this project advanced what is known about those conditions. Faculty are motivated to engage in professional development when they have the leadership commitment, time, resources, and capacity to produce the knowledge they need to be successful in developing new instructional strategies. Capacity building is supported through access to directly relevant and practical worked examples. Math faculty appreciate having models of professional learning and development developed by their math faculty colleagues. 

Further development and testing of the materials field tested at the Broadening Participation in Mathematics through Practitioner Inquiry conference is worthwhile because they are resources for faculty to learn how to increase equitable participation among African American, Latino, and Native American students in math. The impact of the use of these materials on student experiences and outcomes deserves systematic testing and evaluation on a broader scale. That (next) step can only be taken when a critical mass of math faculty are willing to test the materials in their everyday work over an extended period of time.
